summary:
The Security Council, 
Recalling previous resolutions, particularly 1714 (2006), 1709 (2006), 1706 (2006), 1679 (2006), 1663 (2006), 1653 (2006), 1627 (2005), and 1590 (2005), and resolutions 1674 (2006) on protection of civilians, 1612 (2005) on children in armed conflict, 1502 (2003) on protection of humanitarian personnel, and 1325 (2000) on women, peace, and security, 
Reaffirms commitment to Sudan's sovereignty, unity, independence, and territorial integrity, and to peace, 
Welcoming progress in implementing the Comprehensive Peace Agreement (CPA), particularly ceasefire compliance, institutional framework establishment, budget adoption, and new currency introduction, 
Recalls the international community's commitment to support the CPA process, including development aid, and calls on donors to continue support, 
Stresses the importance of elections and force redeployment as CPA milestones, and urges accelerated preparations for elections, 
Calls on the Government of National Unity and the international community to support a successful elections process, 
Welcomes the return of internally displaced persons and the full deployment of UNMIS in Southern Sudan, 
Reiterates concern over restrictions on UNMIS movements and materiel, and calls on the Government of National Unity to abide by its international obligations, 
Expresses grave concern over the humanitarian situation in Darfur, condemns violent attacks on civilians, and reiterates the need for all parties to end violence and atrocities, 
Condemns the treatment of UN, AMIS, and international non-governmental organization personnel following their January 2007 arrests and detentions, 
Welcomes the UN-Government of National Unity communiqu√© to support humanitarian operations in Darfur, and calls for its immediate implementation, 
Commends African Union efforts to deploy AMIS, condemns recent fatal attacks on AMIS, and supports coordinated efforts to implement the Darfur Peace Agreement, 
Notes concern over armed attacks by Other Armed Groups, welcomes the Uganda-Lord's Resistance Army agreement, and commends UN Special Envoy Chissano's efforts, 
Takes note of the Secretary-General's report on Sudan dated 17 April 2007 (S/2007/213).
Determining the situation in Sudan continues to threaten international peace and security, 
1. Decides to extend UNMIS's mandate until 31 October 2007, intending to renew it further;
